Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Wetting Phenomena in Particle-Filled Polymers: Multifunctional Composites with Easy Processability

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Fibers are often mixed into plastics to make them stiffer, stronger, or better electrical conductors. Yet such fiber-containing plastic composites are difficult to manufacture by standard molding or other processing. Furthermore, fibers often suffer damage during manufacturing. This project is to create a bridging system that converts particle fillers into a network of reformable fibers i.e. fibers that are capable of reassembling after breaking. Composites with such network can retain the initial design properties (such as high strength and toughness or high conductivity) without suffering property loss during processing. The Principle Investigators will conduct scientific outreach at pre-college level, especially at the Pittsburgh SciTech High School and two K-8 schools with high minority enrollment, to encourage students to pursue education in STEM disciplines.

The specific hypothesis of this research is that composites containing a fiber-like labile filler can be realized by dispersing solid particles into a polymer matrix, and bridging them together by menisci of a wetting fluid. Since the menisci continuously break and reform during flow, the composites will have excellent processability. The properties of the resulting polymer composites may be tailored by suitable choice of filler, and this project will test fillers that realize composites with high stiffness, or high toughness, or high electrical conductivity. The hypothesis will be tested experimentally using polystyrene as the matrix plastic, and silica or metal particles as the particulate filler. Various thermoplastic materials will be used as the wetting phase that forms menisci between particles. Polystyrene, particles, and the wetting phase will be blended by a melt extrusion process optimized to realize meniscus-bridging of particles. Characterization includes tensile and impact testing, electrical conductivity measurements, and morphological studies by scanning electron microscopy. The intellectual significance of this project is to demonstrate that meniscus-bridging can be exploited to achieve materials with the processability of ordinary particle filled polymers, with the mechanical properties of fiber reinforced composites, or the electrical conductivity approaching metals. Furthermore, this project will advance the fundamental knowledge of capillary interactions in filled polymers.

Performance_Institution.Name: Penn State Erie, The Behrend College

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Multiphase polymers comprising mixtures of one or more polymers and particles are routinely used in daily life in diverse applications, e.g. automotive tires, packaging materials, or fiber-reinforced plastics, just to name a few. In many such applications, the microstructure of the mixtures can greatly affect the material properties. Microstructural differences may include the alignment of fibers, aggregation of particles, or distortion of a minority polymer into elongated shapes. The goal of this project was to test whether capillary forces can be used in particle-containing polymer mixtures to tune the microstructure.

Experiments reveal that a wide diversity of microstructures can be realized in mixtures composed of particles and two immiscible polymers. We have mapped many such microstructures in polymer blends in the simplest case of spherical particles. One major contribution of this research is to show that many of these microstructures appear regardless of particle size, chemical nature of the particles or polymers, or viscosity of the polymers. Thus, we have proposed the concept of a somewhat universal microstructure-composition diagram in such three-component mixtures. In another portion of this research, we have shown that similar microstructures appear when the particles are metallic (copper) and one of the polymers is a liquid metal. This led to the development of "conductive plastics", i.e. particle-containing polymer mixtures that have high electrical conductivity even at modest metal loading. Finally, we have also explored the microstructural map of polymer blends containing an unusual type of particle: fumed silica. In this case, we showed that an unusual type of "co-continuous" microstructure appears very readily. This microstructure, consisting of two phases that are self-connected throughout the bulk, are considered highly desirable in applications in which open pore structures must be combined with mechanical robustness, e.g. membranes, cell growth media, or controlled-release materials.

This project resulted in the training of two graduate students and several undergraduates. This also brought undergraduates from an undergraduate-only institution (Penn State University, Behrend Campus) into research. Graduate students from the University of Pittsburgh benefited from the plastics processing expertise at Penn State University as well. Finally, numerous outreach efforts were conducted at undergraduate or pre-college level to bring the research out of the lab to a broader audience.

 


Last Modified: 11/26/2019
Modified by: Brian Young
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Multiphase polymers comprising mixtures of one or more polymers and particles are routinely used in daily life in diverse applications, e.g. automotive tires, packaging materials, or fiber-reinforced plastics, just to name a few. In many such applications, the microstructure of the mixtures can greatly affect the material properties. Microstructural differences may include the alignment of fibers, aggregation of particles, or distortion of a minority polymer into elongated shapes. The goal of this project was to test whether capillary forces can be used in particle-containing polymer mixtures to tune the microstructure. Experiments reveal that a wide diversity of microstructures can be realized in mixtures composed of particles and two immiscible polymers. We have mapped many such microstructures in polymer blends in the simplest case of spherical particles. One major contribution of this research is to show that many of these microstructures appear regardless of particle size, chemical nature of the particles or polymers, or viscosity of the polymers. Thus, we have proposed the concept of a somewhat universal microstructure-composition diagram in such three-component mixtures. In another portion of this research, we have shown that similar microstructures appear when the particles are metallic (copper) and one of the polymers is a liquid metal. This led to the development of "conductive plastics", i.e. particle-containing polymer mixtures that have high electrical conductivity even at modest metal loading. Finally, we have also explored the microstructural map of polymer blends containing an unusual type of particle: fumed silica. In this case, we showed that an unusual type of "co-continuous" microstructure appears very readily. This microstructure, consisting of two phases that are self-connected throughout the bulk, are considered highly desirable in applications in which open pore structures must be combined with mechanical robustness, e.g. membranes, cell growth media, or controlled-release materials. This project resulted in the training of two graduate students and several undergraduates. This also brought undergraduates from an undergraduate-only institution (Penn State University, Behrend Campus) into research. Graduate students from the University of Pittsburgh benefited from the plastics processing expertise at Penn State University as well. Finally, numerous outreach efforts were conducted at undergraduate or pre-college level to bring the research out of the lab to a broader audience.
